ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Gave me a baseline for astrophysics and sharpened some of my math skills. I definitely learned more about the universe, black holes, and planets.
This was an excellent course for beginners -- I learned the basics of some of the most interesting topics within a complicated and fascinating field.
Learned a lot about rockets, exoplanets, and black holes specifically. Learned many new interesting formulas to calculate various values.

I am much more excited to explore the field of Astronomy! While the name "Astrophysics" seems so daunting, Prof. Geha made the information very accessible! I loved having a class with her--she's amazing!
I learned that astrophysics is an interesting, challenging topic.
I learned so much that satisfied my curiosities about the evolution of stars and planets and I also learned enough about rockets and orbits and gravity to increase my curiosity.
You learn about space, planets, and stuff like that. You learn how to find black holes or exoplanets. You learn to solve some physics problems.
I learned more about space and astrophysics, and I really learned more about how exoplanets are discovered as well as how black holes operate.
learn about black holes, exoplanets, rocket stages and exploratory missions, satellites, etc
I was able to gain a broad spectrum of knowledge regarding introductory astronomy (rocket science, exoplanets, and blackholes).
I learned some base info about rockets, exoplanets, and black holes.
Understanding of black holes, exoplanets, and the basic fundamentals of astrophysics

I learned about basic equations and principles in astrophysics, current hot topics (e.g., what astronomers are looking for on Mars), different ways of detecting exoplanets, and how black holes really work.
I can now say I know rocket science.
I learned about how rockets were launched, how scientists discover exoplanets, and about black holes.

I learned about black hole formation, how rockets work in orbit, and different methods of discovering exoplanets. It helped me understand concepts I previously thought I could never understand unless I majored in astrophysics.
Learned about science writing and how to construct scientific arguments.
The three main topics discussed in class include: rocket launch, exoplanets, and blackholes.
I learned about the solar system and concepts in astrophysics that I had no clue about prior.

After this class, I have a basic understanding of rocket science, black holes, and exoplanets. We also spent time talking about the controversies in Astrophysics, and the areas of research with growing research and breakthroughs.
Great basic understanding of space's biggest questions. Rocket science, exoplanets, and black holes.
Great introduction to interesting topics in Physics! The course covers Black Holes, Exoplanets and Rockets!
I learned a lot about current topics in astronomy, especially about satellites, exoplanets, and black holes.
Basic knowledge of physics, rocketry, black holes, and exoplanets
General topics in astrophysics, exoplanets, black holes, rockets.
Knowledge and insights about orbits, exoplanet detection methods, and black holes. Also cool info about exploration of our solar system

I got a broad overview of astrophysics topics that wouldn't prepare me for the field but will prepare me to have conversations about astrophysics in everyday life, which was all I wanted. I think I will be more able to follow astrophysics topics I see in the news and be able to explain topics to other people more clearly.
I learned about several key areas at the frontier of astrophysics, including black holes, rockets, and exoplanets.
Basic rocket science, exoplanet discovery methods, and black holes - all things I would've never really learned about on my own
Learned a lot about astrophysics and feel as though I now understand topics that previously I did not at all (like black holes).  Learned a lot
I learned about astronomy and astrophysics, specifically the most current research being done in space.
I learned a lot about black holes, science in general, rockets, etc.
Learned all about astrophysics, very insightful
Basic understanding of a few key topics in the astrophysics world, writing press releases,
very interesting concepts related to black holes, exoplanets, easy intro to astronomy
I learned a lot from this course!
Some simple physics and new knowledge about the universe

I learned so much about space stuff. How do rockets work? What is involved in launching rockets? What is escape velocity? What is payload? What are exoplanets? What are blackholes? Why is it hard to escape a blackhole? And just so much more
Learnt a great deal of current topics in astrophysics.
I learned about rocket science, exoplanet discovery, and black holes.
I learned about the foundations of astrophysics, though it is not something I plan to study in great depth.
I gained a lot of knowledge of basic astronomy and astrophysics, and learned how to write about science for an array of audiences.
A brief overview of what it says on the tin
Appreciate the nuances of space, understand the various facets and apply mathematical skills to analyze it.
I learned a lot about the field of astronomy, and gained a basic understand of many valuable concepts in the field.
Rocket science, exoplanets, black holes
I feel as though I gained a much better appreciation of the galaxy in which we live as well as the basics of rocket science.
I learned a ton about all things astronomy - particularly about rocketry with basic Newtonian physics, exoplanets, and black holes, while touching upon General Relativity.
Learned about black hole formations, how to write grant proposal papers and scientific press releases
I learned about complex science topics that were presented in a simple and straightforward manner.
Expands your view on the universe and the possibilities out there
Learned about some prominent topics in astrophysics as well as how the public interacts with astrophysics.

This class gives you an excellent overview of some of the most relevant topics in Astrophysics including Rocket science, Exoplanets, and Black holes. After this class, I have a great understanding of these topics and they have expanded my interest in Astro topics.
Picked up more Hindi
I gained a general knowledge of basic astrophysics in a super fun and interesting way.
I gained an overview of rocket science, black holes, and exoplanets. The biggest insights were just how massive space is and the details of how people explore space.
better understanding of basic astronomy, astrophysics, rocket science, black holes and exoplanets
I developed a better understanding of astronomy and how to use scientific language.

I learned a lot about the basics of astrophysics. I didn't know anything about astrophysics when the class started, and while I can't teach anyone extensively about the subject, I do feel confident about the things that I have learned.
knowledge of astronomy
Learned a ton about basic astronomy. Specifically re: rockets, stars, black holes, exoplanets.
A basic knowledge of space exploration
Incredible foundational astronomy class. Learned about rocket science, exoplanets and black holes. Even if this isn't your chosen major it's absolutely fascinating
Learned the basics of astronomy through studying rocket science, planetary movement/formation, and black holes.
Learned about exoplanets, black holes, laws/treaties regarding space travel, etc.
I gained a lot of knowledge about astronomy and astrophysics covering orbits, rocket science, exoplanet detection, and black holes. My scientific writing skills also improve through the topic papers.
basic understanding of controversies in astrophysics
A lot really enjoyed this course and the professor was great!
The physical laws and formulas necessary to model rocket travel, black holes, and other phenomena related to space; how to be a good scientific communicator
Learned very basic astrophysics, as well as how to write in a scientific style.
I was able to gain an basic understanding of rockets, the formation of the galaxy, and information on black holes.

I got a lot out of this class. It does a wonderful job of going through three different aspects of astrophysics that are all super intriguing (rockets, exoplanets, blackholes). There were so many random terms, equations, or ideas that I had vaguely heard of prior to this class, and it was great to finally learn and understand all of them.
I developed understandings of the process it takes to create, manage, and fly rockets. I have a better understanding of black holes and their creation.
Astronomy

This course consisted of three main topics: rocket science, exoplanets, and black holes. I learned that astronomy (and science in general) is much more than just plugging in numbers into a formula -- there is a lot of interpretation and writing involved as well, which, as a humanities-oriented person, was very interesting!
It was a really comprehensive overview of rocket science, exoplanets, and black holes.
I gained an overview of popular space topics, like exploration and black holes.
Rocket science and basic physics topics, exoplanets and exoplanet detection, black holes
Interest in astrophysics
Very little to be completely honest. I dont think I could recite anything I learned because of how gutty the assignments were
Fun class with great organization and content survey coverage!
I learned about rocket science, exoplanets and black holes
Thanks to this course, I developed a base understanding of several important topics and areas of research in astrophysics. This course also allowed me to gain practice in science writing.
a basic understanding of star & black hole formation, how rocket science functions, and how to detect planets.
In this class, we were taught to think critically about scientific papers, learned some basic formulas of astronomical significance, and learned how to write in a scientific style.

I got to learn a lot about three popular astronomy topics. After the course, I have way more background knowledge about the field and can understand the context of current discoveries/missions. I also learned about science writing and how information is efficiently presented to the public.
Overview of astrophysics
Ability to solve equations related to rockets, orbits, and planet detection. General overview knowledge of exoplanets, rockets, and black holes.
Basic survey class for astronomy/astrophysics- learned about the theoreticals behind rockets, exoplanets, and black holes.
Aerospace engineering and science writing
I learned a basic amount of astrophysics in a variety of topics.
Learned more about rockets, black holes, and exoplanets.
I learned the basics about some interesting topics in astrophysics and how to read scientific research articles.
I learned a lot about the solar system, rockets and the politics of space exploration.
I gained a basic understanding of astronomical mathematics. I learned about how to make science understandable to the average person and how NASA chooses missions.

We covered three main topics: rockets, exoplanets, and black holes. I learned how to apply standard equations to solve problems related to our main topics and how to write about and present difficult concepts discussed in class through topic papers.

I learned about rocket science, exoplanets, and black holes. We learned the basics of Kepler's laws, exhaust velocity, the many methods of discovering exoplanets, the concept of relativity, what a black hole is, what spacetime is... I could go on. I think I also honed more of my scientific and mathematical reasoning skills, as I was initially wary of some of the problem sets, but as we went on, I got much more confident, and they got far easier.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Obviously Zoom made it difficult. The course is good, but feels too simple sometimes. It would be nice to find a better balance between introduction, ease, and complexity.

This course pretty much exclusively has strengths: fascinating course material, intuitive and relevant assignments, and an incredible teaching staff who are capable of making even the most dense and confusing topics understandable and enjoyable. I did not want this class to end.

At the beginning of the semester, some quiz and homework questions were ambiguously written, which made answering them frustrating, but this subsided by the end of the semester and the point totals weren't stressful in the slightest.

Strengths: flexible grading, lower workload, engaging lectures
Weaknesses: none

This class was conducted in the perfect logistical set-up: the breakout rooms helped me know my peers in such a large class--even over Zoom. The recorded content-based lectures and untimed quizzed helped me more fully understand the topics presented in class. Finally, we were able to post any questions we had on Ed Discussions which really helped me understand the topic from the points-of-view of my classmates.
Best course. No changes necessary. Except breakout rooms on the days of psets.
This course was a cool introduction to astrophysics but was quite difficult.

I think more office hours would help. I also felt the grading was a bit intense and harsh. That being said, I felt this class is really interesting, the teaching staff does a fantastic job explaining complex subjects to beginners.

It was a great introductory course for those with low math and physics backgrounds, but it is painfully easy for anyone who took an AP-level physics in high school or an AP-level math in high school. This class is not so much an astrophysics course as it is just a general introductory astronomy course.
very flexible format and accommodating grading structure! no improvements!

Strengths: The class was very well organized with a very reasonable amount of work and a fair grading system.
Weaknesses: There are no weaknesses.
Professor and TA were very helpful with the material and accommodated students according to the needs of virtual semester. The material was also presented in a way that was engaging and interesting.

The course was designed in a manner that focused really on students' learning. The workload was relatively light and the overall atmosphere was relaxed, yet I still enjoyed learning a lot about a subject that I had previous interest, but not much knowledge, in. The Topic Papers were challenging, but creative and fun to work on. In terms of weaknesses, sometimes the pre-lecture quizzes and problem sets had confusing questions (especially on the multiple choice). There were also sometimes small issues with problem set content, but it was not prohibitive. These challenges were understandable, however, given that much of the material was newly developed for this size and online format.
The breakout rooms where nice and I really liked the teaching fellows.
Strengths: Material was taught well, workload was consistent, and I always knew what was expected of me
This course was engaging and fun, but was taught at a relatively low level.

Prof Geha was incredibly engaging and super knowledgable. The clarity of problem sets was lacking a little bit in that they were not phrased clearly to reflect math we learned in class but the TFs and Prof Geha were always ready to answer any questions about them.
Good introduction course. No negatives.

Strengths: Very approachable science credit for a non-stem major. Nearly everyone got an A, and especially with several assignments being dropped (1 out of 3 topic paper was dropped, 1 our of 7 Pset was dropped, several pre-class quizzes were dropped) and lot of extra credit opportunities, it was very easy to get an A in the class if you cared even remotely. 

Weaknesses: The Topic Papers (30%) of the grade was not a great reinforcement or assessment of what we have learned in class. Anyone could have done the topic papers with a little bit of research on their own. Also, I don't think the topic papers had a fair grading rubric as some of the criteria in the rubric included non-astronomy related topics such as the formatting of the paper, the length and wording of the sentences, and the title of the paper. I understand that topic papers were a replacement of the exams, which undeniably lowered our stress, however, I would say the topic papers barely helped my personal understanding of the class content.
It was easy to follow

Strengths: Professor Geha is an excellent lecturer. Making a virtual lecture interesting is very difficult, but she managed to make the live and virtual lectures really engaging. I was initially a bit nervous about taking this course because understanding mathematical concepts is difficult for me; however, she always used metaphors to explain the mathematical concepts in a way that was easily understandable. I learned a lot from this class, and I also really enjoyed taking this class! Weaknesses: This class was a bit more demanding than I expected. The PSets and especially the topic papers took a lot of time to write.
The course was super engaging and the break-out rooms were a great way to allow some discussion about the lecture with others.

S: topic is unbelievably exciting. I have truly formed a passion for the astrophysics that I was exposed to here.
W: none to offer

Strength: Cool concepts, a good surface level intro into the material, very warm and friendly teaching environment 
Weaknesses: the class was VERY easy - almost so simplified that I felt like at times I wasn't really learning that much. I understand that the content is very difficult and complicated and the Professor did a great job of simplifying and presenting the material to a non-science audience, but as Yale students I feel like all of us could have done and learned more than we did. Probably one of the easiest classes I've taken, definitely the easiest at Yale and honestly easier than many of my AP classes in high school which I don't see as a positive.

Strengths: very interesting material, very kind professor. I liked that she tried to enforce watching lectures by having straightforward quizzes. Not difficult. Weaknesses: no complaints off the top of my head, I enjoyed it!
Strengths: Manageable workload, incredibly interesting topic, super nice professor and TAs, lots of options to miss certain assignments but still get a good grade. Weaknesses:  none!

Strengths: Professor Geha is terrific--a great teacher, thoughtful, supportive, and has a unique way of being brilliant but explaining science at the level that non-STEM people can easily understand! Weaknesses: none, really.
Engaging, actually interesting material, and the expectations for assignments/grades is very clear from the start so you know what you need to do, Prof Geha and teaching staff are phenomenal
Strengths - Professor Geha, the grading system, the psets, basically everything, the material

Strengths: very accessible to non-stem or science majors
Weaknesses: the live lectures were engaging but at times felt unnecessary

Strengths: Professor Geha is amazing! The TF's were also amazing. 
Weaknesses: None
Prof. Geha is great at explaining complex topics.
Strength: everything
This course was great!
Tough to say during a pandemic. Given the circumstances Prof Geha did an excellent job
NO don't change the course in any way, if you do you will be ruining it. This class is perfect as it is.
This course was really well thought out. I really enjoyed it and dont see much room for improvement.
This course could be improved if it were in-person because it could be more interactive.

The course is very interesting, and I like that it was broken down into three main units. I think the class could have been improved if the live lectures went into more detail about information raised in the prerecorded lectures, rather than the question/answer format.
I felt like the topic papers were creatively fun, but also felt arbitrary at times especially with no precedent to work off of.
I wish we had field explorations using telescopes, etc. but overall the experience was great.
It was a great course overall that will only be strengthened by returning to in person classes.

Strengths: loved the prerecorded lectures, loved the creativity of the assignments, loved the in-class breakout rooms
Weaknesses: sometimes the quizzes were a little stressful. But all very fair and manageable.

Strengths: clear pre-recorded lectures, many TFs available to answer questions, and Professor Geha is fantastic 

Weaknesses: None
The course is literally perfect in the form that I took it. I genuinely couldn't think of any improvements to the course.

Strengths: Great class for non stem majors and it is well structured. Also really creative assignments that get you excited about what you are learning. 

Weaknesses: A lot of weekly work - quizzes for every class and psets
Love Marla and the wag the course was structured. For accessible for non science majors.
Geha was amazing. Materials were interesting. Work was engaging. If you do the work, you succeed. No weaknesses

I think the class was very well run. Additionally, the material was interesting and the psets were not too long. The topic papers were a little bit off putting and I may have preferred exams, but the prompts were certainly interesting to think about.

This class is amazing! Prof. Geha is awesome and cares deeply about her students and the topic materials. The class is very engaging and not too difficult for non-science majors. There are few ways that this class could have been made better.

The strengths were the teaching staff and their care for the material, and the structure of the class itself. It was very fun learning environment focused on helping and aiding the students instead of making it more difficult during this hard time.
The course was generally engaging and gave an overview of a variety of topics. That being said, it was fairly low workload and didn't require a high level of engagement.

strengths: super interesting material, amazing professor and TF team that were great at explaining difficult concepts, short papers instead of exams
weaknesses: consistent workload throughout the semester with prerecorded lectures and short quizzes due before every live lecture, but never overwhelming.

The recorded lectures and notes and Ed Discussion posts made this class extremely accessible for me. Online classes often affect my ability to focus on the material but the resources provided helped me tremendously. 
I did have a hard time participating in the large group discussions. The breakout rooms were sometimes really great, and other times they were not. It depended largely on the group of people you ended up with. Overall though, I appreciated the chance to get to know other students and discuss my ideas in a smaller group.
Strengths: excellent and fascinated content. Weaknesses: I think it wouldve been nice to do more hands-on work with that content (math, scientific explanation, etc.), instead of writing.
Some of the class seems like busy work.

Marla & Co. were really incredible  responsive, actively engaged, kind. No objective major improvements can be made to the course other than possibly uploading prerecorded lectures a bit more consistently ahead of class. I do want to say, keep the papers! I think I got a lot more out of them than exams.
The professor is amazing
Fascinating material presented in an interactive and unique way

I think Prof. Geha and the TFs did an amazing job with ASTR 160 especially in light of the pandemic. I think the course structure was very helpful in facilitating learning while not adding stress to the students. The topic papers were a cool way to explore the subjects more independently too.
This class was very accessible to non-majors, and I didn't have difficulties worrying about my math skills.
Professor was amazing courseload was amazing
This course was strong!

The teaching staff was incredibly enthusiastic and flexible. You could tell that they just wanted students to have a fun time learning about astronomy topics while not overwhelming them with information that can become incredibly complex.

I don't really think this class could improve for an online format. It was designed fairly and interestingly. It wasn't a difficult class, and that was the point of it. It was made to help non-STEM majors enjoy science, and it did that 100%. I loved that we had Topic Papers instead of exams, and I think most people did. Great chance to be creative and think differently.
The strengths are that the essays are a great way to understand the three topics that are taught within the course. A weakness is that the pre-class quizzes are sometimes difficult to stay on top of.
Recorded lectures

Strengths: Professor Geha! She is very engaging and genuinely cares about the course and her students. The material of this course is also very interesting.  If you have even a remote interest in astrophysics, rocket science, exoplanets, or black holes, take this class. The math is not challenging, and you learn a lot even though the workload isn't high.
Weaknesses: none really.
I loved this class! I think a more effective structure would've been virtual lectures with optional sections for the question sessions, but as it was the class was still good.

This is a fantastic course for non-science/non-astro majors. The emphasis/encouragement to ask questions builds a very friendly environment to learn. The course material is intro-friendly and Professor Geha does a wonderful job of simplifying complex topics when necessary. The psets were also very manageable and the topic papers were fun to write.
- weakness- could give more personal feedback

Strength: biggest gut of all time
Weakness: breakout rooms were immensely boring and a lot of people would skip them
Great style, focus, and assignments for non Sc.
The course is quite strong as it is. Perhaps one of its main strengths is that it gives the students an opportunity to ask questions to Prof. Geha directly.

strengths: All of it, in particular how Professor Geha/the TFs made the content accessible for those who had little to no college math/science experience. Also, there was a whole lot of grace extended throughout (grade drops, extra credit, assignment extensions, etc.) The class felt like Professor Geha said "I love this stuff and want to make it available for others to appreciate as well."
The professor and TFs were very engaging, and the material was easy to digest and interesting, taught in approachable manners.
Its overall a great class but the recorded and live lecture is a bit too much

Strengths- supportive staff, straightforward content for non-STEM majors
Weaknesses- I wish we'd received more guidance on the topic papers. The rubric was really specific and it seemed like we glossed over a lot of it.
It was very comprehensive and interesting, but I think that the recorded lectures were very long and could have been given during class time.
No weaknesses. Great class
Great course all around, no suggestions to change. I want to specifically praise the grading format.
Very great course. Well organized and very helpful during this pandemic/zoom year.

Strengths: the class was exactly as advertised; the papers helped apply what we learned in class; the lectures were easily understandable
Weaknesses: the live lectures felt useless at times
The course was well structured, the grading was transparent, the lectures were engaging, and the content was fascinating!

Just about all strengths for this class. The recorded lectures were brilliantly planned and executed, and a ton of work was put into this class outside of class time. The Ed Discussions board was fantastic as a resource, from asking inane questions about course logistics to course material. The TFs were equally as accessible as the Prof. Geha, and shared a wealth of knowledge. If I had to come up with some weaknesses, I think some of the grading was a little harsh for the topic paper assignments, and some of the pre-class quiz questions were a little ambiguous, but given the number of possible points, it was very feasible to do well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms were nice to speak to other students, but other than that, little to no engagement. I'm not entirely sure how it could be improved. Recorded lectures in addition to live ones were unnecessary, in my opinion.

I liked the topic paper format (rather than exams); it felt like I really had the chance to apply what I was learning to an interesting niche topic. As well done as Prof. Geha's recorded lectures were, I think this would make a great in-person lecture. The Ed Discussions board worked well for this class, and the teaching team was really patient and quick to respond.
Recorded lectures were great as it helped me fit them wherever into my busy schedule.
The use of breakout rooms, Ed discussion, and recorded lectures along with live lectures was very effective in helping me learn all topics presented.

The pre-recorded lectures were great, as we could watch at our own pace. The content of the live lectures was not relevant towards our coursework, and so students were less incentivized to actually pay attention during these lectures, but it was cool to see the extrapolations from the course as well as to have other students' questions answered.
I think the recorded lectures were very effective. Breakout rooms were a great way to foster engagement and discussions.
The pre-recorded lecture wasn't ideal, I would've preferred it to be as part of normal lecture.
I thought that watching lectures before class and then having questions answered during class was an effective format. The breakout rooms were, for the most part, relatively engaged in my experience.
It kind of all worked well enough.
The course facilitated virtual engagement well by using Ed discussions.
This class was great despite COVID-19!
I liked having pre-recorded lectures especially for a STEM class because we could go back and watch for clarity. The use of EdDiscussions was really good for quickly answering questions.
Recorded lectures was the most helpful practice.
Recorded lectures and synchronous lecture (which was used for Q&A sessions) were great!
I thought the way in which this class was set up was perfect for a virtual lecture. It was a big success!
Break-out rooms were great.
Professor Geha's lectures were very engaging.
I really liked the breakout rooms that were used in every lecture. It actually let me get to meet some students in my class, which I didn't really get the chance to do this year
I liked the virtual recorded lectures for homework. The psets through gradescope ended up working well.
I thought the combination of short pre-recorded lectures and longer synchronous lectures worked great. The Q&A format was creative and fun, and encouraged me to ask good questions!

succeeded: hybrid style classes, engagement with professor and with other students
could be improved: more concrete content (or maybe structure?) for the live lectures would have been helpful
Everything was adjusted according to the pandemic! Really great class!
Virtual lectures good. Could make sections more effective

The instructor and TAs made real effort to make the class challenging, however I don't find Q&A particularly interesting since we know so few about astronomy to ask insightful questions. May be more interesting to cover more topics.
The pre-recorded lectures into quizzes were a good way to grade participation
I think it worked well
Pre recorded lectures were good
Breakout rooms helped with engagement
The breakout rooms could be improved, but I liked that we could rewatch recorded lectures.
I didn't like the precorded/live lecture format. I found them redundant, and didn't have much motivation to engage with the live lectures.
Marla was a wonderfully accommodating teacher and met all of our needs, bless her heart.
Very well-structured course
They did great at managing the online format.
I thought the pre-recorded lectures were great, but I didn't gain as much from the live lectures.

Everything Professor Geha did provided the best possible course to take under COVID circumstances. From the split lecture style, to the way that assignments were assigned and dropped, to the decision to swap exams for topic papers, all of these decisions produced and unforgettable class.

I liked having the asynchronous lectures be the material heavy part of the class. I also think the shorter synchronous portions was very much needed. I don't know if I needed so much question time during synchronous lectures. The teaching staff was very active on ed discussion as well which was appreciated.
This class was very well geared for the COVID situation and the professor had very clear and reasonable expectations for how the class should operate.
Everything was great, the only weakness I would mention is it was easy to get by without attending the in person lectures.
I thought the format worked well.
everything was fantastic!
The recorded lectures, ed discussion posts, and canvas quizzes worked really well for me. I think most, if not all, of the COVID practices aided my understanding of the course.
I liked the use of town hall meetings for questionsvery fun to adapt the course to what students were interested in!!
Zoom classes were always engaging by relying on breakout rooms and discussions
I enjoyed the balance between recorded lectures that were informational and the synchronous Zoom calls that answered questions we had about the lectures.
I think that the topic papers replaced the midterms (I'm not sure) but I thought this was a good change because I learned a lot from writing the topic papers but didn't feel overwhelmed.

The break-out rooms were a success. It might be better if the break-out rooms stayed the same for a longer time. It's more difficult to build a social rapport over Zoom, so staying with the same cohort for longer could be better.
Recorded lectures were very helpful
Very successful best professor
In the online format, things were a little trickywe had to watch a full recorded lecture for every live lecture, which amounted to quite a bit. Other than that, though, no notes.
I enjoyed the grading system. It was easy to be able to understand what exactly you needed to do in order to gain a specific grade.

This is a copy and paste of the previous answer--I don't really think this class could improve for an online format. It was designed fairly and interestingly. It wasn't a difficult class, and that was the point of it. It was made to help non-STEM majors enjoy science, and it did that 100%--but I'll add that the lecture quizzes and ed discussion were a type of virtual engagement that I found enjoyable. Besides the break out rooms, however, there wasn't really any engagement with other students, but you can't hold that against a virtual lecture.
I think that learning engagement could be improved. I thought that the breakout rooms were only thing that connected students with students and that was not much.
Recorded lecture

Successes: the asynchronous lecture format + the quiz assignments were really useful in making sure I understood the concepts
Improvements: the synchronous portion could have included a bit more lecture material
The structure could've been better as explained above to make the lectures more engaging.

I really enjoyed the lecture structure of the course: asynchronous lectures in preparation for synchronous lectures (which were about one hour). The asynchronous lectures allowed me to understand the material at my own pace, and the synchronous lectures were always interesting because they directly addressed student questions. The shorter length of the synchronous lectures allowed me to be more engaged and prevented exhaustion.
- having question answer sessions

Hard for me to say what the course is normally like but it was clear a lot of effort was made to adapt to the virtual format, and I think it was largely successful. Breakout room sessions were especially engaging, to talk and meet with other students.

added flexibility is helpful with zoom learning  zoom school is particularly detrimental for those with psychological/academic disability and added accommodation or attention paid to those who need those requests/reaching out would be helpful
recorded lectures being much longer and informational than in-person ones & leaving class as a Q&A. Deadline extensions in response to what was going on during the semester.
The integration of pre-recorded segments to allow for more discussion in class was very useful.
I thought the course format was well-suited to virtual learning, especially the decision to change the exams to topic papers throughout the semester.
I thought that both the live and recorded lectures were very comprehensive.
They all succeeded. The lectures were great and assignments very accessible for online.
The live+recorded lecture combo was extremely cool
Very enjoyable during covid. No weaknesses.

Shortening both live and recorded lectures was great because my attention span through Zoom is so short; getting rid of exams was helpful because I actually learned through writing papers instead of exams

The recorded lectures made learning course material very flexible, and the synchronous lectures geared towards questions posted online made it easy to discuss complex topics. The breakout rooms during the synchronous lectures also provided an opportunity to meet and discuss with other students taking the course.

Pre-class quizzes with fewer ambiguous questions! I think EdDiscussions was a brilliant resource, too. The recorded lectures, while I was initially not super pumped about that, I changed my mind and found it nice to be able to play them at 2x speed and go back to them if I needed to check on the content.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you are looking for a science credit as a non-major student, which is who it is intended for.

This is an incredible course for anyone (STEM or non-STEM) who has at least a little interest in space (and no real background in it). The teaching staff and especially Prof. Geha have an unmatched ability to demystify complicated ideas and concepts, and the work actually felt relevant to the material without being overwhelming. I always looked forward to recorded lectures and live sessions, and I wish the class wasn't ending so I could keep learning more.
YES! One of the easier science credits, and you still learn a lot about space in a simplified teaching method.

Yes! This course is great for students of all interests--STEM to humanities majors and anything else! It's very versatile and appealed to a wide range of my friends. For example, two of my friends who were in the class were Econ and American History majors. I am a STEM major, and we all enjoyed the class!
Yes. Unequivocably. Accessible to people that aren't good at math but still really interesting. Love this class.
Yes. Astro is a cool topic! But be prepared to grind these psets. They were quite challenging mathematically.

As a History major, this was by far my favorite of the four QR/Sc credits I've taken to fulfill distributional requirements. Prof. Geha is wonderful, astrophysics is a cool subject, and the course was very well organized. The perfect science for non-science majors class!
Yes! A great class to get a science credit. It has some challenging aspects, but if you know little to no science, this is the class for you.

This course is a great science gut. It is, however, not the most entertaining class in the world, and likely going to be your least interesting class in whichever semester you take this course. But it's an enjoyable course and the professor is great.
absolutely!!!!! this is a fantastic class that is super interesting and engaging but also very low-workload

Absolutely! This is a great class to take to expose yourself to the basic fundamental knowledge of astronomy. Very interesting topics and the course was very well organized. I received clear feedback on my grades which was great.
Yes, if you are looking for an interesting science gut, take this course.
Yes, for anyone that is interested for learning more about astrophysics.

Yes, absolutely! This is a very relaxing, low-stakes class that allows students to develop a solid, basic understanding about astrophysics. If you used to be fascinated by planets and black holes but have not learned much about them in high school, this is a wonderful and fun class to take.
Yes but I fear telling more CS majors about this class will overflood it again.
good gut
Yes! Great class if you need a science credit!
Yes, it's a fun and easy course.
YES! Prof Geha is amazing and you will learn interesting concepts in a easy-to-understand way
Yes. For non-STEM students, this is a great introduction science class.

Yes, especially if you are looking for an easy science credit. Nearly everyone in the class got an A/A-, so if you want an easy 5th class, this is the class for you. Professor Geha and the TAs were passionate instructors and they were very friendly. Workload for this class was also very manageable, and the topics are fairly interesting compared to other gutty science class.

Yes! Super fun and easy science credit. I learned a ton about astrophysics in an easy to understand way. Professor Gehia is wonderful and engaging. If you are looking for an easy and fun science gut this is it!
Yes! This is a great class for students who do not consider math to be their strong suit but still want to learn about Astrophysics concepts.
Yes, an amazing science credit for anyone with a slight interest about space.
Definitely recommended especially if you're looking to complete your science credit as a non-science major! A fun course which won't overly burden you!
Yes, especially if you're interested in space! The topics are really interesting and Professor Geha is very engaging. You'll learn about satellites, exoplanets, and black holes.
Absolutely!

If someone is looking for an easy class to learn basic surface level science information then absolutely. If someone is looking for a spring board into more science or is genuinely curious about the material, maybe a higher level class would be better.
Yes! It's a great science credit that's approachable for all majors.
Yeah, its actually very interesting! Cool perspective I wouldnt have gotten otherwise. Really liked the stuff about exoplanet and black hole detection

Definitely! I think the topic will be interesting to everyone, no matter their major or primary interests. It's really important to be able to situate ourselves in the universe we live in, and this class did this really well and opening my mind to all the amazing things around us. The workload is low and completely manageable. Amazing choice for a Sci/QR credit.

Absolutely, especially if you're scared of math/science (like me) and you just think stars and rockets sound cool. That's basically what this course is about! Professor Geha is fun and engaging, even to those who thought this would just be checking off a distributional requirement!

Yes! It's great if you need a fifth class or want a fun science credit for a non-STEM major. It's pretty easy to get an A, and the teaching staff want the class to be interesting and manageable, and the weekly problem sets aren't too bad. It does take a little more to do well on the topic papers, but grading is fair and communicated extremely well (probably the best managed course I've taken so far)

YES.  Best science class ever.  Grading is very chill and you don't have to do all the assignments to get an A.  Low stress.  Learned so much and Professor Geha is amazing and really focuses on student learning.
yes, it's a very good science credit for non-stem or science majors.
Yes! If looking for a science credit or just interested in astronomy, take this class!
Yessir
Yes 100%. Learn a lot, chill atmosphere and the breakout rooms work really well
Yes for gut
Yes, good fifth class
Yes
Yes

science credits don't get better than this. I took biology, the world and us last semester and had to credit d because it sucked. You must take this course if you're looking for a science credit. Just make sure to check that they haven't changed from the spring 2021 format because I believe this was the perfect format.
Yes! Great science credit where you learn a lot.
Yes!
Absolutely. A super fun class that is *very* low stress. If you do the bare minimum, you should be walking out with at least an A-
I would recommend this course to other students, especially if they are not STEM students.
I would recommend this class to a student who needs a QR/SC credit and want to dip their toe into astrophysics.
Take it if you want a science gut, otherwise go take another astr class
Yes, very engaging. If you always wondered about space, insights into how it operates and exists, this is a great class!
Yes, its a great class.

Best science class Ive taken at Yale. If youve ever looked up at the sky and been interested in the stars, the planets, or any part of outer space, you should take this class. Marla provided a great survey and scientific literacy builder on all things space. I really enjoyed this class!
I would recommend this course to another student. It provides a great introduction to several interesting topics in astrophysics and presents the content in a way that is easy to follow.
Yes 100% take this if you need a science credit

This is hands down the best class I've taken at Yale. If you are at all interested in space in any capacity, please do yourself a favor and take this class. If I wasn't so far down my major, I might've switched to an astronomy degree.
Yes! Especially if you are looking for a science credit
Yes. Take this class if Geha is teaching it.
Absolutely. It is so phenomenal in its content and teaching
Yes, it is a low stress class that still teaches you a lot about an interesting and engaging subject.

I would most definitely recommend this class to another student! It was an amazing class to take, especially for a non STEM student. This is a perfect science credit and it was not too difficult. It also was an amazing class, each bit of information seemed relevant and extremely interesting. Could not recommend more to other people who need their science credit.
Yes, a great fifth course!
Yes, it is a wonderful science credit that is super interesting and engaging.

I took this as a science credit. To be honest, it was more of a gut than I expected, but still had interesting sections and good takeaways. It's worth it if you need the credit, but I think there are better options if not.

absolutely!!! amazing course if you need a science credit or are just interested in astronomy or astrophysics. this was a fantastic course and I'm so glad that I decided to take it! One of my favorite classes I've taken at Yale
Yes! absolutely LOVED this class. so much fun and learned a lot, and the workload was pretty low. definitely take it if you have the chance

I would! Prof Geha is so nice, and she really does go way out of her to make sure people are accommodated for and learning as much as they can. She extended the deadline for a large assignment because of Ramadan. I think this is a really great class to take if youre a non Stem person because its not too too challenging but youll still learn a lot. Seriously, getting an A is very achievable with all the support systems they put in place.
I would recommend this course to another student. If a student struggles with the sciences or is looking for a class to help get them into science again, this is perfect.
Yes. The class is interesting, engaging, and conducive to learning. Also, I think its really cool that I know this much about black holes now.
yes
Yes. Good SC credit for people who are average at math & want to know about space! Interesting with a good professor, very well organized.
Yes I would. Low stress environment where I learned a lot!!
Yes! Prof is awesome
YES YES YES!! This course is so incredibly fascinating, I would recommend it wholeheartedly
Yes, interesting and easy science credit
Yes definitely!
Yes, I would strongly recommend this course. Even if you have studied physics before, you will learn a lot of cool things about our solar system and universe, and the course is fun.
Take this class! Amazing professor and fascinating content.
Yes loved professor Geha and the class
Yes! Fantastic science course for non-stem majors
I would recommend it to other non-STEM majors looking for a science credit.

If you are in search of a gut science course this is definitely the class! It is both enjoyable and informational without getting to difficult. It is also a good taste of astronomy without becoming a major.

I would definitely recommend this course. If you need a science or QR credit, TAKE THIS CLASS. It is fun and easy, and the teaching staff is sweet and engaged. The professor and TAs really care about the students. If you don't need a science or QR credit, I'd recommend this class anyways. I found so much of it engaging and interesting.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. I was able to learn the process of writing a scientific paper.
Yes, its fun
Absolutely! This course is incredible for non-STEM-oriented people, and I found it incredibly approachable despite the daunting nature of the topics.

YES! If you are even remotely interested in black holes, rocket science, exoplanets, and NASA, take this class. It's fun, and Professor Geha is great. You learn a lot despite a relatively low workload. The grading is also very clear and transparent.
Yes! It was a great introductory class for someone who knows very little about space and was often daunted by heavy math.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially anyone new or intimidated by science classes. The lectures are friendly and interesting, and the psets are not overly complicated but challenging enough to test your understanding of material. Professor Geha is also an engaging and kind instructor.
Yes, highly recommend for non science majors

If you need an easy science credit take this. Each pset took 15-20 minutes and it was once a week. The drop the lowest scores of each type of assignment so it makes it super easy to get an A (a lot of people didnt have to do the last two weeks of assignments)
Great class for non-Sc people!
yes, especially for science credit  very doable, even for those who arent very stern inclined
Yes, interesting science class if not STEM

I would absolutely recommend this course to anyone who is at least somewhat interested in astrophysics. I came into this course with little to no base knowledge about the topic. Because of the engaging learning format where we were encouraged to ask questions, I managed to learn more about it.
100% if you're looking for an easy but informative gut.

Yes, if you have an interest in the topic. If you're nervous about getting a science credit, this is a great course for you. The prof makes sure everyone gets the help they need to understand the material and succeed. If you put in the work, you can get an A fairly easily, though don't take that as a reason to not do the work or not put effort in, because then you won't be happy with your grade.
I would recommend this course as an introduction science class, especially for those who have little math/science backgrounds.
Yes! I think it's a great course for anyone looking for a science credit.
Yes
Yes
Yes absolutely.
Yes, for a science credit that isn't technical or mathy. You learn a lot of interesting topics.
Absolutely. Amazing content and professor
Yes, if they want an easy but interesting class.
Yes. The material and Prof. Geha are both amazing.
10/10 recommend for non-STEM majors to get a basic fluency in some scientific topics and to get that Sc credit

Yes! This class was awesome! Professor Geha was an incredible professor who understood the difficulties students had this semester and adapted her class to help us the best she could. Even as a humanities person, this class was interesting and I found myself wanting to pay attention in class. I would suggest this class to anyone who needs a fun SC/QR credit.
Yes. This is a great science credit for those non-stem people looking for one. Very interesting material without a lot of hastle.
Yes! Great science credit for non-stem majors that care about the why science and astrophysics are relevant in today's world
YES; if you are non-STEM and slightly interested in studying the heavens, this course was so good. It was a great introduction to the study of astrophysics with a very managable workload.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student, no matter their major or experience with astronomy. The course material is interesting and explained well, and even though there were many students enrolled, the semester was very well-structured.

Yes! But it is NOT A GUT. Don't believe what others say. If you treat this as a gut, you can do well. If you pour your time into the class, you'll get an A. The work in this class is extremely fascinating, sometimes extremely difficult to understand, but you'll be astonished when you can comprehend rocket science by the end of the first third of the class. Professor Geha is a gem of a lecturer, and explains things in easy to understand words and examples. Our P-Sets had fun problems on them, like calculate the exhaust velocity of the fire extinguisher Wall-E uses to move on the spaceship in the movie. This was a fantastic class to take for my dreaded SC/QR credit, so I'd 100% recommend it to someone who doesn't freeze up at the mention of numbers and equations. There is a fair amount of math in this course, so heed those warnings about comfort level in math. But otherwise, find a partner or someone to work with, and you're gold. The topic papers were a brilliant change from exams, as I don't think I'd have done well on exams. We wrote a NASA mission proposal, an exoplanet press release, and a dumbed down explanation of black holes (which I didn't even have to do, as I had gotten the sufficient number of points to get an A!). You'd be a fool not to take this class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lecture and live virtual lecture.
Combination live virtual lecture and recorded lecture
Recorded lecture + live virtual lecture
Live and recorded lectures
We had a twice-weekly recorded lecture followed by Tuesday/Thursday classes to address lector topics in a more informal manner and to complete breakout room questions.
A combination of recorded lecture, synchronous class, and optional synchronous break out rooms.
Combination: recorded lecture and live virtual lecture.
It was a combination of live lecture, asynchronous lecture, and discussion board questions and responses.
Also a live portion.
Recorded lectures as well as live virtual lectures were used in this course.
pre-recorded lecture with live lecture as well
Recorded lecture and live virtual lecture
Combination of recorded lectures and live virtual classes.
This course consisted of a recorded lecture as well as a live virtual lecture.
N/A
We had to watch recorded lectures prior to class, and then attended live virtual class sessions in which the professor and TAs answered questions and we had short discussions in breakout rooms.
We had 2 synchronous lectures and 1 asynchronous lecture every week.
Live virtual lectures and recorded lectures
The course also had live virtual lectures that expanded on material learned in the prerecorded lecture.
recorded and live lecture
Recorded lectures and in class Q and A periods
Recorded lecture with non-recorded in person aspects.
recorded lecture and live virtual lecfture
This class was a mixture of live virtual lecture and recorded lecture. Once a week we had a live lecture to answer any questions we had on the recorded lecture, which we watched for homework.
recorded lecture before each live class.
Recorded lectures plus a live virtual lecture.
N/a
Virtual live lectures in conjunction with pre recorded ones
Recorded lectures
As selected
Recorded lecture with live Q&A sessions and breakout sections.
This course was a combination of recorded lecture and live virtual lecture.
Pre-recorded lectures and synchronous discussions.
This class was half recorded lecture and half live lecture.
Live virtual lecture with pre-recorded lectures to watch before the actual lecture.
Great class
Also recorded lectures + virtual sections
plus a recorded lecture
Live virtual lecture combined with asynchronous videos
Introduction to astronomy
Half recorded lectures, have live virtual lectures
No other modes
Recorded pre class lectures
And live lectures too
Recorded lecture with live q&a/lecture/breakout room discussion component
Pre-recorded lecturs with live component
It was a combination of a recorded lecture and a live virtual lecture.
a mixture of recorded lecture and live virtual lecture
Both live virtual and recorded
A combination of recorded and synchronous lecture
N/a
Recorded lecture
recorded lecture
We had a live virtual lecture coupled with a shorter recorded lecture.
Virtual lecture and in person question answering component
Recorded lecture as well
mix of recorded and live virtual lectures
Combination of synchronous and asynchronous lectures
In combination with pre-recorded lectures.
Hybrid of synchronous and asynchronous.
Live virtual lecture with recorded lectures to watch before hand
N/A
both a precorded lecture + live virtual lecture
Live q/a and recorded lectures.
Recorded lecture and virtual lecture.
It was a mixture of synchronous and asynchronous lectures.
recorded lecture and virtual discussion
We had two recorded lectures every week, along with a large virtual lecture.
Recorded lectures and live lectures.
It was a combination of recorded lectures and live virtual lectures.
In-person lecture & recorded lecture
Virtual break-out discussion rooms.
there was also live lectures to supplement recorded content.
Some recorded lectures
Virtual lecture with additional live lecture/Q&A components
recorded + live in person lecture
Recorded lecture with in person lecture
A combination of recorded lecture, live virtual lecture and section.
There was both a recorded and live portion to this class. Our lectures would be recorded and required to watch prior to live meetings, which I enjoyed.
Live virtual lectures
Na
The course consisted of a combination of recorded lectures on content and then live Q&As.
This course was a combination of recorded and live virtual lectures.
recorded lectures with virtual question sessions and breakout rooms
Recorded lectures and live virtual lecture
Mix of recorded and live
There were also recorded lectures for pre-class viewing
live virtual lecture
recorded lecture
Live recorded Q&A and pre-recorded lecture
Besides meeting live (virtually) each week, we also watched recorded lectures.
Combination of in-person and recorder virtual lecture
We had both recorded lectures, and live virtual lectures for this course. In the live virtual lectures, our professor also incorporated breakout rooms (so virtual discussion time)
recorded and live virtual lectures
Pre-recorded lecture videos to supplement discussion style lectures. Breakout rooms for solving a question of the day.
A mix of recorded lectures, in-person discussion and question/answer, as well as additional TA hours and a discussion board
Live virtual Q&A lecture.
Recorded and live.
There were 30-minute recorded lectures to be watched before each non-recorded 1-hour Zoom lecture (2x per week).
Pre-recorded lecture and live virtual class discussion
I attended live virtual lectures and watched recorded ones.
both live virtual and recorded lectures
combination of live virtual lecture and recorded lecture. Each live recorded lecture included 20 minute breakout rooms which were akin to discussion groups.
Online videos with an in-person class in more depth.
pre-recorded lecture and quizzes, live discussions
There were 30-minute recorded lectures that we had to watch before the live lectures.
Async pre-recorded recordings
Recorded lecture with a live virtual lecture component

It was a mix of both live virtual lecture and recorded lecture. We'd watch a recorded lecture before class, take a short quiz, and then come to class to have questions answered and work on a question with a breakout room group.
